Interesting because the GG imprint is still present despite a change of masterblender at the controls nose: peppery spices are in the foreground, where the fruit salad is much more pronounced than the leading product of GMS fresh, intense fruit, a blend of natural peach and artificial with a very strong sweet taste, a malty return mouth: The good side of this product are the stubborn scents that make it different from other distilleries, it's fresh, it is almost drunk more than it tastes, the squeezed fruits are very sweet on peach, apricot, dry oak. , in short better than it seems nuts a little roasted in return to calm this riot of fruit, well the spicy return is felt final: Long, fruity and spicy, simple but intense. More interesting than it seems.

reviews.content: After a short whisky evening with a few disappointments, I wanted to finish with a whisky that surprised me positively and that I could simply enjoy. I could hardly have made a better choice. I would wish for such honest whiskys more often and I'm sure they were made for such a simple pleasure many years ago. The price is outstanding and I would prefer this malt to any young and overly barrel driven SV at 55 percent for 90 euros.
reviews.nose: 88.5 For anyone who can enjoy a Glen Grant Standard, this easy bourbon aging nose is to die for. Full honey notes with vanilla, hazelnut and Christmas apples. Percentages and age go together perfectly here at Glencairn. With the 15 years and the 50 percent this is just a perfect dram to end a nice evening with a delicious whisky. There isn't much to discover here, but when a whisky is made so beautifully simple and yet intensely clean, you don't always need to discover it.
reviews.taste: The start is strong, full, ripe and characterized by sweet butter cake and honey. For my taste it could have been 5 percent less, but you can easily achieve that in a 3cl sample with 3-4 drops of water. If a slight sympathy for middle-aged Glen Grant maturations should have an influence here, I beg your indulgence. I just really like the light wood note with vanilla of such whiskys. For some connoisseurs, this is only 84-85 points, because it seems too boring. That's okay and understandable. This just goes to show that whisky is a matter of taste and many people don't prefer this to a blatant sherry sweetness. Everyone has to decide for themselves and that's totally ok. I am happy about every message and invitation that suggests an evening together with the two contrasting aroma profiles.
reviews.finish: 86.5 A medium-long interplay of sweet and bitter aromas. Simple but good.

reviews.nose: spicy, apple compote with a hint of cinnamon, honey, vanilla sauce, roasted almonds, pear juice, but also a bit of alcohol, a slightly sour note of apple cider vinegar
reviews.taste: Here too, a spicy start, nutty, creamy, vanilla pudding, green apple, black pepper, slightly unripe pear, honey, a little black coffee
reviews.finish: walnuts, coffee, oak spice, green apple and vanilla

reviews.content: S 7 I can’t tell if there’s any fruit when having it neat, it’s rather malty and bourbon-like. Adding a few drops of water elevated the nose and palate with fruits while shortening the finish. Can’t really say it’s a “fruit bomb” like how it's described by others here, but very professionally crafted. [78-82] I'll gladly welcome another dram.N 25 Oaky and vanilla. With a few drops of water, the juicy fruits finally surfaced. Half-ripe banana, red apple, a whiff citrusy. The spirit strength, however, also became more noticeable. P 26 Way more sophisticated than my expectation drawn from nosing it. Creamy, sweet malt, and a lot of peppery spices that gradually smoothen out. Subtle honey running behind. Then elegant wood fragrance arrives with a faint amount of orchard fruits (red apples, white peach). Water enhanced the fruits to add an extra layer of complexity. F 23 Mid, mildly dry finish. Freshly baked loaf with warm spices lingering.
Great whisky to just drink

reviews.nose: Nose is slightly closed to me. Vanilla and caramel are noticeable, but fruit and sweetness are only timid. Citrus fruits, apple, a bit malty, butter biscuits, maybe a subtle almond aroma. With a little more time in the glass, a subtle alcoholic sting is added. Not exactly uncomfortable but a bit annoying. Still a very good nose.
reviews.taste: Sparkling, spicy, more sour after citrus, grapefruit, some gooseberries. More intense on the palate. Honey sweetness with butter almond cake, slightly floral, the 2nd sip seems slightly alcoholic to me, a bit spicy. Oak spice is slightly dominant and suppresses fruit and sweetness a bit and then also seems bitter to me.
reviews.finish: Medium-length finish, vanilla, banana, honey sweetness, still slightly bitter,

At the bar.

Initially, a malt covered in a fresh bourbon blanket, I was very disappointed. With time, I am stunned by how lovely this is, and completely won over. Totally my style of whisky, could have this every day. Despite what most people say, I think this behaves well with water. It’s quite spicy neat, so you’ll want to experiment if you want to get to the gentler floral and fruity notes.
reviews.nose: A little bit of a prickle at 50%. Very buttery, with lots of orchard fruit and plenty of spice. Apricot, peach, pear, apple, orange, lime perhaps. Honey and yellow florals. An intentional composition, the blender knows exactly what he’s doing here. Vanilla, tonka bean, cinnamon, hints of pastries but not too bready - this one is all about the fruit. Hint of lily of the valley, and even an acquatic / ozonic tinge - makes me think watermelon.
reviews.taste: Just a very pleasant mixture of sour and sweet on the tongue. The citruses gain a bit of ground compared to the nose. Developer nicely from soft fruits to spicy buildup. Heavy herbal honey, lemon and orange, peach, apricots, sweet apple, sourdough.
reviews.finish: Fairly dry but not overly so, plenty long for the age. The fruits continue, supported by nice bready notes and some herbs. Massard put it very well below - simple but intense.

reviews.content: Malty, fruity nose (ripe, orchard fruits), where a few drops of water open things up, allowing through vanilla caramel, oak and biscoff biscuits. Very similar profile on the palate, although the alcohol burn is more noticeable than on the nose, definitely needing water to tame it. A drying, slightly metallic note emerges late on, and dominates the medium-length finish more than I’d like. Very fresh and lively nose and palate, then, only let down slightly by the finish.Edit: got a lot sweeter and the sharper edges disappeared as the bottle got under half full. 85 fresh pour. 87 now. Updating score to average of 86.

reviews.nose: first oak, then typical ExBC notes. Caramel dominates here, vanilla is only subtle in the background. The 50 volume percent are not noticeable in the nose.
reviews.taste: Again, first the wood. In addition some sweetness and a few light fruits, reminiscent of mashed pears. Here the 50 percent by volume is now clearly perceptible. With a drop of water then again a good deal more intense and voluminous.
reviews.finish: Medium long, slightly bitter. Nothing special for a 15yo.

reviews.content: Tasted at distillery. Glen Grant's single malt, matured for 15 years in a combination of ex-bourbon and ex-sherry casks. Bottled up at a hearty 50% ABV, it boasts a bold, fruity profile with plenty of vanilla rich oak char. I further get banana, caramels , almonds, brioche, reminds me of bread and butter pudding. Could sip this all night.

reviews.taste: Strong, floral, sweet, some oak, lemon drops.
reviews.finish: Very sweet, light fruit, becomes dry and spicy.

reviews.content: Vanilla, fruit, lemon.Very smooth, honey, creamy.Pepper and honey

Trying the standard Glen Grant 15 Year Old – Batch Strength 1st Edition (New Label) right after sampling the standard Glen Grant 12 Year Old (New & Old Label) was a great way to see how additional years, and a higher ABV (50%) can help enrich the Glen Grant flavor profile.This was definitely a bottle I could see myself enjoying regularly, sharing with friends and it brought more insight into the core Glen Grant character. Onto the Glen Grant 15 Year Old (Old Label) next…
reviews.nose: On the nose, the standard Glen Grant 15 Year Old (New Label) immediately stood out over the 12 Year Old we just tried, with a stronger, richer Manuka honey note, bolder caramel and vanilla notes.
reviews.taste: There’s a medium coating mouthfeel, with some ginger right on the front palate, the higher ABV is felt from the start. And similar to the nose, the palate of this standard Glen Grant 15 Year (New Label) featured a richer flavor profile, with stronger ripe apple notes, baked apples, stronger honey and caramel notes, reflecting what I got on the nose.
reviews.finish: Long finish, with fading prickly ginger spice, honey, barley sugars, just a pleasant finish.

reviews.content: Glen Grant 15YO Category: Single Malt Producer and bottler: Glen Grant Distillery (Campari) Region: Speyside Strength: 50% (barrel) Bottling series: Batch Strength - 1st Edition Volume: 1000 ml (Duty Free) Barrel type: 1st fill ex-Bourbon Bottling date: LR0/FG 20 Min. age: 15 years Filtration: none Dye: no Nose. Orange confiture, lime, pear, honey melon, red apple with cinnamon, apricot, baked butterscotch, herbaceous notes, vanilla, ginger. As you can see, it continues the line of its predecessors - the same bright fruity profile, but noticeably spicier and with a greater influence of wood. Adding water enhances the fruity tones. Taste. We took sliced fruit (red apples, pears, apricots), added cinchona bark, malt, poured floral honey on top, melted creamy toffee, sprinkled a little lime juice for sourness and, so that the resulting cocktail was not too cloyingly sweet, added a fair amount of spices (orange zest, vanilla, cinnamon, ginger). The whisky has good density, a “fat” creamy vanilla texture and a good balance in taste. Aftertaste. Medium to long. Noticeably dry. Orange confiture, red apple pulp, malt, vanilla, ginger. Summary. An excellent representative of pure bourbon aging in the Speyside style, uncomplicated, a little straightforward, but bright, powerful, fresh, sweet. "Fruit bomb" as it is. It may seem too spicy, especially for beginners, but that's why it's cask strength - just add water! I personally prefer Highland bourbon makers, who seem more austere, elegant and intelligent, but here one cannot fail to note the skill of the wizards from Glen Grant - they have produced very high-quality whisky. Score: 85 out of 100.
